results.title: Bighorn: Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep, Banff and Jasper National Parks
results.creator_credit: Bill Schmalz, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A far closer view, and a more complete one, than even the hardiest and most patient of visitors is likely to get of the bighorn mountain sheep of the Canadian Rocky Mountains. “Bighorn” is a film distinguished by its camerawork (Bill Schmalz). It catches the characteristic behavior of the bighorns from birth to mating time. Few animals are more arresting in appearance or activity than these dancers of the high ledges. Awards: Novi Sad; Spindleruv Mlyn; Philadelphia; Tarbes.

results.title: Biggie and Tupac
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Broomfield, Michele D'Acosta and Lafayette Films
results.brief_description: Flawed but intriguing documentary from Nick Broomfield, about the deaths of rival African American rappers, Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls. Tupac Shakur was born into an impoverished and fractured family life, but went on to become a hugely successful musician; Biggie Smalls came from less humble beginnings but was similarly successful in his field. Once close friends, these two became bitter rivals in a gang war between rappers and their entourages on the East and West coasts. By interviewing a slew of the pair’s contemporaries, including Biggie’s mother, Broomfield investigates the possibility that Death Records impresario Suge Knight murdered the two and that the LA police were complicit. Broomfield certainly stumbles where angels fear to tread, including a visit to prison to interview Knight, as well as filming some very agitated characters, presenting an ambivalent but fascinating portrait for the viewer to draw on.

results.title: Bigfoot in Harry and the Hendersons
results.creator_credit: William Dear, Richard Vane and Universal Studios
results.brief_description: George Henderson (John Lithgow) is on the way home from a camping trip with his wife Nancy and children Sarah and Ernie, when he accidentally hits and kills what seems to be a wild animal. A closer inspection reveals what they all believe to be the mythical ‘Big Foot’. Visions of richness are revealed to George, and against his family’s wishes, takes the dead creature home with him. Later that night, strange noises wake the entire family, who go downstairs to find Harry, the Big Foot they killed, is actually alive. Their lives are turned upside down by Harry, who destroys their house, but gains their love. The Hendersons decide the best thing for Harry would be to return him to the wild, but before they can, he escapes. Hot on his trail are amateur hunters and professional ‘Big Foot’ hunter, Jaques Lefleur (David Suchet). The family, with the help of environmentalist, Dr Wallace Wrightwood (Don Ameche) race against time to return Harry to his home - before he ends up in a zoo.

results.title: Big Wednesday
results.creator_credit: John Milius, Buzz Feitshans and A-Team Productions
results.brief_description: Set between 1962 and 1974, “Big Wednesday” is the story of three surfing friends - Matt, Jack and Leroy. We see their loves, fights and the hero worship that follows them as they conquer the waves. The South Swell 1962: the three rule the waves. Together with their friends they get drunk, go on surfing holidays and have wild and destructive parties. As the years pass, the Vietnam War and growing up take their toll. They witness the changes in themselves, their home and friends. The Great Swell 1974: Matt, Jack and Leroy re-unite to brave one last journey together, to surf the great swell. “Big Wednesday” encapsulates the emotions of passing youth against the splendour of the sea and surfing. Includes a special appearance by surfing legend, “Mr. Pipeline”, Jerry Lopez. Cast includes: William Katt, Gary Busey, Jan Michael Vincent, Patti D’Arbanville and Lee Purcell.

results.title: Big Bill: the story of a heron
results.creator_credit: Anthony Bomford, Hugh Miles and RSPB Film and Video Unit
results.brief_description: This beautifully photographed film looks at one of the most well-known water-birds, the grey heron. Habitat, nesting, breeding, raising the young and collecting food are aspects of the heron’s life that are examined. Narrated by Eric Thompson.

results.title: Big brother of Christmas Island: Tai Ko Seng [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mathew Kelley, Peter Du Cane, Samantha Kelley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the significant role Gordon Bennett played in the development of the union movement on Christmas Island. Bennett immigrated from England to Australia and quickly rose in the union ranks. In 1979 he arrived at Christmas Island to help the workers union improve worker conditions. He was responsible for significant changes and during his twelve years became a folk hero to the local inhabitants.

results.title: Big boys don't cry
results.creator_credit: Tee Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: A young boy wanders through bushland enjoying nature’s beauty. Carrying a slug gun he initially shoots at a paper cup, however images of TV western gunfights go through his mind and on impulse he takes aim and shoots a bird. Realising what he has done the boy runs away as scenes of real life violence flash before him - scenes of war and innocent killing. The boy makes the decision to return to target shooting. A non-verbal film with b&w sequences. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Beyond the rift wall
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Gobeil, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: A film about a group of farmers and their wives who went to live and work among the Tanzanians, training them in Canadian methods of grain growing and production. It examines the cultural effects of this exchange both on the Canadians, who found themselves isolated by geography and language, and on the Tanzanians who were exposed to Canadian work habits and technology.

results.title: Beyond the naked eye
results.creator_credit: Claudia Overing, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film of marvels, an amazing view of the living, pulsing universe contained in a single drop of water from a fish aquarium. Colour film and a microscope, and the infinite patience of the filmmakers, reveal life that no-one would ordinarily see. This is a view of creation, of birth, life and death, of the laws of nature that apply even to the smallest of living things. It is a film that will add knowledge and insight to the pleasure of any audience. Photographers: Eric Chamberlain, Claudia Overing. Narrated by Sharry Plett and Albert Martin. Awards: Tehran; Belgrade; Melbourne.

results.title: Beyond the frame (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: B.Z. Vincent-Batyka, Royal College of Art (Great Britain) and Tate Gallery
results.brief_description: In attempting to break down the barriers between art galleries and the general public, the Tate Gallery gives lectures to groups of adults and is involved in a special program for children, called Kid’s Play, to help them appreciate the different types and forms of art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: B.Z. Vincent-Batyka, Royal College of Art (Great Britain) and Tate Gallery
